0:01 Mom I can explain

There are a few unusually large single-celled organisms out there.

To my knowledge, all of the largest are plants, which means that they're not as reliant on diffusion as bacteria. Still, it's more important for them than for a multicellular organism. They can produce their own energy, but they still have to get the resources for that inside their enormous cell body (along with other nutrients that they need to build their components) and to get waste products out.

The way that they function is illustrative of the point this video makes. Most are "huge" only in relative terms, like bubble algae. They can be seen and could presumably be meaningfully handled, although I feel like they'd probably be too delicate to handle very much or roughly. Any issues they have with surface area vs. volume are probably minor enough to solve with "clever" energy use and proteins to facilitate diffusion. Things get really interesting, though, with the largest ones.

Marine plants in the genus Caulerpa can form what looks like a carpet on the sea floor. They're based around a stem-like stolon, a tube with its length measured in meters, and can have hundreds of fronds that look a lot like the ones on a fern. Those similarity are just an example of convergent evolution, though. The plant is a single-celled green algae. Where most plants use fronds or leaves to maximize surface area available to capture sunlight, Caulerpa species have a cell membrane contorted into the same shape to maximize surface area for diffusion. Where most plants use stems to circulate nutrients, Caulerpa uses its stolon to circulate its cytoplasm to the same effect. Cells that huge have multiple nuclei, building proteins throughout their body.

The Bacterium was measured up to 0.75 mm in size, which is large enough to easily see by the naked eye! Isn't this amazing?!

There is a single celled organism that is far larger than 1mm, in fact it's even bigger than an insect. It's the Caulerpa, a kind of green Algae. So a bacteria might be able to get larger but would need to evolve some very specialized organelles.

A teacher of mine had a neat way of demonstrating this. we simply gathered four of us. one to represent the intake of the cell, one to represent the outtake of the cell, and two others to represent the intake and outtake of nature or the world outside. We started close by each other, and our goal was to pass a ball between each other. It was a very easy ordeal near each other, as we could simply pass the ball with a simple outreach of our arms. But then she got us to stand further apart, requiring us to throw. It got harder, we had to toss the ball and took time by aiming and sometimes we had to go pick up the ball. Next she got us to do this from the corners of the class room and it got mega hard, the ball almost never took a direct trip and it regularly dropped, and we had to take extra time with aiming.

In hindsight, it wasn't exactly the best demonstration, perhaps a 'timer' of 5 seconds could have been added to represent the cell's time left alive before lack of passing the ball kills it, but we got the general idea. It at the very least explained to us why cells would rather become multicelluar rather than become just a big ol' cell.

It's actually a scary lot like programming when you really think about it. A lot of modern developers wouldn't understand because they don't realise the amount of syntactic sugar, which would be a full human for example, while older developers had to still "build" that human with all those tiny clumps of cells. In the end, the syntactic sugar (modern functions you can just call upon whenever you want) is actually just a wrapper for a lot of pre-made functions. So, very much like a 'human', said functions still go back to the very roots of programming, which is 0's and 1's... Bits. These bits get clumped together per 8, to make a byte (compareable to a cluster of cells). Every pre-made programming function really isn't anything other than if statements and loops. "If 1 then " and "if 0 then", repeated thousands of times (loops) to eventually pretend as if "stuff just works". Much like how we don't actually see our bodies working and how many extremely basic stuff happens on a small scale, to eventually connect it all into one big scale working thing, is how syntactic sugar works for programming.

Great video, however I think it didnt address one of the biggest difference between single microorganisms and multicellular organisms. It is true that the cube law affects diffusion, but the main reason that limits the cell size is the available energy. In prokaryotic cells, the energy available is proportional to surface area, and the solution to that problem was mitochondria, that is the key element  of all complex life, cells now can produce energy in huge larger scales than the surface area limitation. That allows eukaryotic cells to especialise in all the diversity of life we can see today.

This does not really answer the question of how large a bacterium (it is "one bacterium" but "many bacteria") can get. The largest known bacteria, Thiomargarita nambiensis get to about 0.75mm in diameter and are roughly spherical shaped.
However there are other single cell organism that are much bigger, some of those can get up to several cm big. e.g. Valonia Ventricosa which get get up to a few cm and is spherically shaped or Acetabularia which can get up to 10 cm and is more disk-like shaped (which is more advantageous then spherical shape when it comes to surface to volumn ratio).
Caulerpa can get to up to a square meter in size and have a complex, flat, leaf-like structure which again helps to maximize the surface area for that size. All the big singular cell organisms live in the water, which makes diffusion easier.

you never answered the question in the title numb-nuts! What is really holding a bacteria back is not the square cube law. The square cube law only is true relating to squares. No DUR. Its why life pretty much is never a square. Take humans for example because of our elongated shape the average male has a surface area of 1.9m^2 and volume of 0.6m^3.  Kurz would have you believe that by a scale of ratio our volume is larger than our surface area by a factor of ten however the opposite is true. Humans have a lot of surface area compared to volume. Bacteria however are held back in reality by two factors cytoplasmic streaming and the absence of a nucleus. Cyclosis is a complicated subject but long story short bacteria are terrible at it and it makes transporting through the cytoplasm difficult. Additionally Eukaryotic organisms can be much larger than prokaryotic because of Eukaryotic cells ability to be Multinucleate. types of sea weed can be unicellular by having multiple nuclei. Bacteria don't have nuclei which would make it difficult for a host of reasons to be larger. BUT TO ANSWER THE QUESTION How Large Can a Bacteria get? about 0.75 mm if the bacteria exists in a long thin form that maximizes surface area.

Hi folks, biophysicist here. I'm glad to see some cellular biophysics content videos featured on your channel! While this was a neat introduction to passive diffusion, I hope one of your future videos will mention the importance of facilitated diffusion, active transport, and other molecular processes that "beat" passive diffusion and are essential to cell function. For example, even at the small bacterial scales like the video mentioned, passive diffusion alone isn't sufficient for many processes, like removing toxic compounds from the cell interior. And at larger scales, like the human ovum (~100um), passive diffusion would be far, far too slow for signaling processes like preventing fertilization by multiple sperm. It's important to note that passive diffusion is only one part of signaling and transport in cells, and only one reason among many of why cells have the wide variety of shapes and sizes they have. And most importantly, it's why an embiggened bacteria might have an easier time living than you might expect!
2:50 Diffusion isn't about molecules bumping into each other - it's just about probability, a less likely state (low entropy) to a more likely state (high entropy)

The largest insects were believed to be about the size of a cat or small dog.

Diffusion of gases/nutrients between a single-cellular organism and its environment is not the ONLY limiting factor of a bacterium's size, right? For example, would it be technically possible for there to be a massive single cellular bacterium that still has the same surface area to volume ratio of a microscopic bacterium if the mega sized bacterium had a very, very, very folded/cell structure? I imagine there are reasons why super folded and super large single-celled organisms never really came to be (maybe it's the fact that bacteria don't only need to diffuse gas, but also transmit information within the body itself, or maybe the fact that a typical bilayer cell wall wouldn't be able to hold the weight of a massive, super folded cell structure?)

Almost four years ago I had an experience that truly changed my life. In February of 2017 I was deep into drugs and substances. I had an addiction to Methamphetamine and Synthetic Marijuana. One day I decided that I was going to use K2 and Methamphetamine simultaneously, and I did so. After I did this for about three days I began to become paranoid, but I wasn't to concerned about being paranoid because I knew that Methamphetamine made me paranoid in the past. But this time was different, after going several days without using the drug I still felt paranoid and it was gradually getting worse. During this time of torment, the four closest people in my life had found out something terrible that I hid deep in my past, and began to torment me about it, they would talk about it in such a way where only I could understand what they were talking about and there was nothing I could do about it other than to sit there and be scared about if I was going to make it through another day without being hurt by my own family, I was only 17 years old and I felt completely powerless.

At the time I did not believe in God, but I thought "If there is a God, He is the only one that can get me out of this mess." As the months went on I began to search after God with my whole heart, doing things I had never done like praying, studying the Bible and singing spiritual songs and lifting my hands in the air. And there came a day when I was listening to "Start Over" by NF and I said these words "Lord, look into my heart, you know that I want to do this more than anything else" and for the first time in my life God spoke to me, it was a very deep, loud voice and spoke like one having great authority and power and He said "I know Andrew"

Regardless of all the years of sin and everything that I did against God that broke His heart, He still knew my name. I couldn't believe that God spoke to me, I was saying "HE KNOWS MY NAME HE KNOWS MY NAME, THE GOD OF THE UNIVERSE KNOWS WHO I AM" And that is when I realized I was not alone in that storm and that Jesus was going to deliver me and was going to use my failures to help other people who are stuck in the same place I was. He will reveal Himself to anybody who searches after Him, but the decision is up to you and the ball is in your court.

would the folks at your channel be interested in doing a video series on plant physiology?
i think audiences would benefit a lot from an understanding of plants' basic needs.
for example, we all know that plants' leaves gather co2 from the atmosphere, but did people know that their root systems need also need atmospheric oxygen in the soil?
this is why many varieties of plants die in overwatered soil, because their root systems are literally drowning.
the only exception to my knowledge is rice, contrary to popular belief they don't necessarily need tons of water, they are simply able to survive without having as much oxygen, i think likely because they are monocots, whereas weeds are not able to survive in flooded soil because most weeds are dicots, making flooded soils easier for cultivating rice with a decreased factor of pestilence, that's another wonderful thing about plants, their physiology can vary as greatly between their families as animals, like with homeotherms and poikilotherms, and carnivores and herbivores.

6O₂ + C₆H₁₂O₆ = 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + Energy (in form of Adenosine Tri-phosphate) This is Cellular Respiration (combining oxygen with glucose to get energy, also why organisms exhale carbon dioxide and water vapor)
6CO₂ + 6H₂O + Energy = 6O₂ + C₆H₁₂O₆ (This is Photosynthesis, it stores energy into glucose, combines sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to store energy inside of glucose, this is why plants exhale oxygen)
Both plants and animals do cell respiration, but only plants do photosynthesis. We need plants to survive, and they need us to survive.
Diffusion: a form of passive transport, or movement across the cell membrane (the outer layer of the cell) that requires no energy, as it moves down the concentration gradient (high to low).

Makes ya wonder why the Universe wants to observe itself so damn badly, so much that life fights like hell not to die.

Like Carl Sagan said, we're the Universe observing itself. For example, if I mix vinegar and baking soda.. is that an emotion? Can you feel anything from it? no? Then why is it when you have complex chemical reactions occur in your brain, you "feel" something from it. What is that "feeling"? Chemical reactions occur everywhere, the ones isolated in this head of ours are done in such a fine tuned way, but regardless they're just chemical reactions.

So if they're just a process we already understand, then why is we can "feel" this feeling from it? What is that damn feeling? Its a real aspect to reality because we're part of this reality and we experience it, but how?

A chemical reaction occurs and somehow, on some other level "something" (us) exchanges this information into some form of non existent "feeling" of love, or hate, or anger, or happiness. Same applies to Color, wtf is color? Our eyes are sensitive to specific wavelengths of light thats all, but the chemical reactions in our skull somehow are interpreted by whatever we are as "colors". Red, blue, orange, green etc, these don't exist outside of our awareness.

This is why consciousness is weird, because its something on a whole different level. Sure, its "just chemical reactions" but its the experience of the chemical reactions that create an awareness and what is that? Is it the energy itself released by these reactions that are somehow alive and able to feel the environment utilizing this biological machine? Is it the Universe itself experiencing what itself feels like by hovering over these finely tuned chemical reactions when they occur to create some awareness?

A chemical reaction doesn't explain feelings, they occur, and feelings are interpreted from them by something. Something is "experiencing" these reactions as these non existent feelings.

Breathn't

You know all those little "balloons" in the lungs? Emphysema destroys the barriers between them, leaving you with larger air sacs, and therefore less surface area to transfer oxygen and carbon dioxide. Not only that, but it can lead to other potential serious issues, such as air leaks, occurring either on their own or as the result of medical procedures.

My dad has emphysema and just spent over six weeks in the hospital, because what was supposed to be a "simple" surgery to remove stage one lung cancer from the bottom of his lung resulted in tearing the lung tissue on the complete opposite end from where the cancer was. He was left with a huge air leak that required more (failed) surgery, and chest tubes connected to suction to keep the air pulled out of his chest to avoid his lung collapsing from pressure building in his chest cavity upon exhaling (because not all of the air leaves your body through your mouth anymore). Ultimately we were sent to another hospital where one-way valves were inserted into his brochi to block off that entire lobe of his lung. Despite all that, he STILL has a small air leak, requiring a chest tube and external heimlich valve, just so that he could finally go home from his hospital prison. It's healing so slowly that they frankly don't have any idea when the hole will seal, if ever, or whether the valves should ever be removed to restore the lung capacity that this procedure blocked.

Don't smoke, kids. Just don't do it.

Sometimes it's sad to know a lot about science cause most videos I already know about but it's still fun to watch. But I do have the opportunity to add something here: Brownian motion (the mathematical calculations that you use to explain diffusion) increases speed when the particles are exposed to higher pressure or heat. Heat is often hard to change significantly on earth but if you use very high pressures you can actually build some ENORMOUS cells which is where we find some of the biggest single cell organisms.

If you're big on math just look up "brownian motion" and play around with some theoretical planet-sized cells on jupiter or something

Okay, maybe a dumb question, but what about organelles? Many of eukariotic cells' organelles used to be life forms of their own, but they got swallowed up by the bigger cell and formed a symbiotic relationship. Couldn't there theoretically have been a smaller cell that was really good at moving oxygen around, and that got swallowed by a eukariote that could then grow a little bigger by letting this new organelle randomly pick up and drop oxygen a little faster than diffusion could? Then, they could have co-evolved to signal pick up and drop off, and to cut the ATP costs of the movement, letting the cell grow even bigger, and so on, right? I mean obviously, if that happened on Earth, that line got outcompeted into extinction by multicellular organisms, but is it even technically possible? Or am I going off the rails?

Does the square cube law suggest a particular factal dimension would be optimal I guess in the limit as the dimension of the boundary of something as the size increases?
Like, say, given a certain rate of exchange needed per outer volume, and a rate of exchange per surface area, and then some other contribution for the costs of being very wrinkly, can one get some specific "if you scale up lengths by this factor x, you should scale up the 'content' of the boundary by factor y" and therefore get an ideal fractal dimension out of it?
I realize that irl objects are not actually fractals because at some level you get down to atoms, which is why I was saying if you take the limit as the size goes to infinity (which is meant to be analogous to if you take the limit as the length of the measuring stick your are using to describe the fractal goes to 0 (like, with the coastline paradox))
edit2: found a study which says "The mean value of the 3D fractal dimension in our patient cohort was 2.35 (range 2.21–2.44), which is in good agreement with previously reported values from similar studies" so that answers that question.

Reasons I love Kurzgesagt
1. The Narrator. I swear if you fire them, I will strike. Well, probably not, since I love this channel, but still.
2. The Animation. Every scene is something to look at, it is stunning. Amazing job animation team!
3. The information. The fact that you all show your sources, while also make an easy to digest, animated, video. It is amazing!
4. The Availability. You could get this on Hulu or Netflix. No doubt. It could definitely be on Amazon Prime. But the fact you make this free shows how much you care about educating the world. And mostly the youth, you can't deny it.
5. The demographic. I am 13. I love watching these. My grandpa is 65. He loves watching these. You have made a series that anyone can watch and love.
6. The conclusion. I am going to say it right now. You are the new Bill Nye. Take your seat among the champions. Carl Sagan, Bill Nye, and Neil Degrass Tyson, just to name a few. I hope you see this, and you know that you deserve every subscription and more.
Edit 7. The Music. Check the replies to see who said it, but I totally agree. The music is amazing.
Edit 8. The Team. I can not stress enough how great everyone on this team is. Everyone only thinks about the Narrator and the Animators, but there are so many more people than that making each and every episode that we all love.

I’m not a huge fan of how they represented diffusion. Diffusion isn’t some mystical force of nature that causes molecules to wander from high to low concentration places. Low concentration places have molecules moving to high concentrations at an equal speed. It’s just that there is more in the high concentration, by definition. So even though the say 49% of molecules are in the low concentration, potentially ‘wandering’ to the high concentration, the remaining 51% in the high concentration can also go to the low concentration, and when more molecules leave the high concentration than go to it, you get diffusion. The point I’m trying to make is that at the individual scale, there is no tendency to go towards low concentration areas, it’s just when you look at the bigger picture that diffusion emerges, so when they have animations of molecules magically pushed into the low concentration area, or through the cell membrane, it’s simply not accurate. Molecules don’t diffuse; concentrations do.

I have a question about surfaces for Kurzgesagt or anyone willing to answer:
throughout the whole video it talks about surface area being very large despite how low the volume is, take for example the lungs or tree leaves mentioned. I was wondering if it was similar to the coastline paradox? Basically it says that by changing the resolution at which you want to quantify a coastline length, it varies and goes up to infinity as you increase the resolution. So by looking at the surface area of smaller things and comparing it to bigger things (surface area of a tree's leaves vs surface area of the internal structure of all the leaves of a tree) aren't we just increasing the resolution of how we quantify the surface thus making it look bigger and bigger the smaller we look?

"size of a blue whale" is poorly phrased.
Size is nonspecific.

How about a bacterium the Mass of a blue whale.

Then it can be a much larger (in two dimensions) while much smaller (in its third dimension).
Then, it is folded (like making the multiple layers of pastry dough) while leaving space between the layers (like the fins on a heatsink ) then add in a rippling behavior that moves water through those spaces and you have an ocean biome bacteria the "size" of a blue whale (larger actually due to all the "open space" inside the bacteria).

Technically diffusion does require energy. If everything were at 0K you wouldn't see any diffusion. The system itself must have energy in order to be capable of diffusion, and diffusion consumes energy in different forms, one form being heat energy as the molecules bump into each other causing the system to lose energy.

TLDR: Diffusion requires energy, its not free

wow 27,030 views already????

Over millions of years, our genomes have picked up a vast amount of DNA from dead viruses. Each of us carries almost a hundred thousand fragments of endogenous retrovirus DNA in our genome, making up about 8 percent of our DNA. To put that figure in perspective, consider that the twenty thousand protein-coding genes in the human genome make up only 1.2 percent of our DNA. Scientists have also observed millions of smaller pieces of “jumping DNA” in the human genome. It’s possible that many of those pieces evolved from endogenous retrovirus, having been stripped down to the bare essentials required for copying DNA.

"Thiomargarita is a close relative of these bacteria, but unlike their smaller cousins they are unable to and do not need to move constantly up and down to get nitrate or sulfide. With the much larger pools of nitrate, stored in the vacuole, and sulfur, stored in the periphery, Thiomargarita can survive for at least three months without external supply of either substrate. In the loose and unstable sediments off Namibia this enables them to lie in the sulfide-rich sediment and wait for times when a passing storm transports nitrate-rich seawater into their surroundings. As an adaptation to this mode of life, they are surprisingly resistant to extreme conditions such as high concentrations of oxygen or sulfide, which would kill Thioploca."
